title: How do pets navigate?
intro: We hear stories about pets who manage to find their way home, even across hundreds of miles? How do they do it? Neil and Dan explore some of the theories in this episode of 6 Minute English.
this_week_question: How long is Omar, believed to be the world's longest cat?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: something which is easily recognisable and helps you find your way
a piece of metal which attracts certain metals

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Welcome to 6 Minute English, the programme where we bring you an interesting topic and six useful words or phrases. I'm Neil.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And I'm Dan. Today we're talking about one of the last mysteries of science. No, not if the universe will keep expanding forever, but this: how do cats and dogs find their way home over long distances?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: We hear incredible stories of lost pets travelling tens and even hundreds of miles home – but scientists struggle to explain how they do it.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: We'll hear the view of one scientist today. But before that – I have to ask an important question: Neil, are you a cat person or a dog person ?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh, that's easy – I'm a cat person , for sure. Dogs are just a… well, they are hard work, aren't they?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: If you say you are ' a cat person ' it means you prefer cats. ' A coffee person ' prefers coffee. A 'something' person likes or prefers that thing, often over another thing.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Back to the topic, I'm a cat person . But can you answer this, Dan? Recently, a cat called Omar made headlines for being, possibly, the world's longest cat. How long is Omar? Is it…

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I'm gonna say c) 180 cm.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now, from long cats to long-distance cats. Scientists were scratching their heads a couple of years ago when a lost cat called Holly travelled 200 miles to get home. How did it do it?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: We say you ' scratch your head ' when you are confused about something. There are a few theories about how cats and dogs navigate – but we don't yet have the full answer.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, both cats and dogs have an extremely powerful sense of smell, of course. Smells are like signposts – they let you know where you are. Visual landmarks also play a role, just as they do with humans. A landmark is something very easily recognised – a big building or mountain for example.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And what about this one: magnets are pieces of metal which attract certain other kinds of metal - for example, iron or steel. The Earth itself has a magnetic force.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Birds use it to help them navigate over thousands of miles – it tells them where north is. It's thought they have some iron in their beaks.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: But some scientists think mammals also have this capability.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So we have a few ideas – smell, landmarks , magnetic forces – but can we explain how one kitty travelled over 200 miles by itself back to its home?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Let's hear from cat and dog expert Dr John Bradshaw. How do cats build up the maps in their heads?

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr John Bradshaw, School of Veterinary Sciences, University of Bristol What they do when they are in a new territory is explore it in a very systematic way. So they will go out in ever-increasing circles, they'll literally construct a mental map in their heads. And so a cat that's lost its territory probably does the same thing. They'll rely on the idea that if they go out in ever-increasing circles or rectangles then eventually they'll either come across the territory or they'll come across a smell carried on the wind of the territory that they used to live in and then be able to go home.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Cats have a systematic approach – which means they use a system . Which is: first they walk around their area in a small circle, then a bigger one and then a bigger one – until they have a strong mental map of the place.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes – a mental map is a map in your head – stored in your memory. And the area cats explore – their home area - is called their territory . Cats are territorial – which means their territory is very important to them.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Having a map is great, but what happens when a cat gets lost? Dr Bradshaw says that again, it moves around in bigger and bigger circles, until it finds a clue – which is a landmark or a smell – that tells it where it is. Well, that's the theory. Though Dr Bradshaw says we really still don't have enough data – that's enough information about this.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: When there is a scientific breakthrough - we'll bring it to you in 6 Minute English, I hope. For now, let's content ourselves with Omar, possibly, the world's longest cat. How long, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I said 180 cm.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Omar measures 120 cm – that's over two thirds of my height – and weighs a heavy 14 kg.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, one thing, Neil, if Omar ever got lost, he'd be found in no time.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: He's a landmark in himself! Which reminds me – let's run through today's words again. If you're a cat person , you prefer cats. If you're an evening person – you prefer evenings.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I've always thought you were a kind person, Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Nice of you to say, but we only use the phrase with nouns, not adjectives!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Indeed. We don't want the listeners to be scratching their heads .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No, we can't confuse them! So let's explain the next one clearly – a landmark is something easily recognisable that lets you know where you are. The bridges in London are landmarks .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And can we say the parks are magnets in summer? A magnet is a piece of metal that attracts iron and steel – but we can also use the word more widely to describe things that attract other things. Two more words: territory is a noun – the area of land that an animal considers to be its own.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Animals who feel this strongly are described as territorial . Humans can be too – about land or subjects they feel they own or control.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And finally systematic : the adjective from system. We can talk about a systematic approach, a systematic solution, a systematic study…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And we have systematically worked our way through all of today's words!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Very good! Which means – it's time mention our own online territory – our website and social media pages.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Check us out on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube, and of course bbclearningenglish.com!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Bye bye for now.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye!
